words.meaning: A song of praise or triumph.
examples: The book is a paean to the beauty of the natural world.
The poet wrote a paean to his beloved city.

words.meaning: Done with or employing great care and thoroughness.
examples: The artist's painstaking attention to detail was evident in every brushstroke.
She gave a painstaking account of the events leading up to the accident.

words.meaning: Pleasant to taste; acceptable or satisfactory.
examples: The chef managed to make the unusual ingredients into a palatable dish.
The compromise was not ideal, but it was palatable to both sides.

words.meaning: Resembling a palace in being spacious and splendid.
examples: They lived in a palatial mansion with a swimming pool and tennis courts.
The hotel lobby was palatial, with marble floors and crystal chandeliers.

words.meaning: Prolonged and idle discussion.
examples: I haven't got time for all this palaver; let's get straight to the point.
The endless palaver in the meeting achieved nothing.

words.meaning: A manuscript or piece of writing material on which the original writing has been effaced to make room for later writing but of which traces remain.
examples: The ancient manuscript was a palimpsest, revealing layers of forgotten history.
The city's architecture is a palimpsest of different historical periods.

words.meaning: A dark cloud or covering of smoke, dust, or similar matter; a cloth spread over a coffin, hearse, or tomb.
examples: A pall of smoke hung over the city after the fire.
A pall of sadness descended upon the mourners at the funeral.

words.meaning: Make (a disease or its symptoms) less severe or unpleasant without removing the cause.
examples: The medication was intended to palliate her pain, not to cure her illness.
He tried to palliate his friend's grief with comforting words.

words.meaning: Pale, typically because of poor health.
examples: Her face was pallid and drawn after her long illness.
The pallid light of the moon cast eerie shadows on the ground.

words.meaning: Able to be touched or felt.
examples: The tension in the room was palpable as they awaited the verdict.
There was a palpable sense of relief when the storm finally passed.

words.meaning: (of an amount) small or meager.
examples: She received a paltry sum of money for her hard work.
His paltry excuse for being late was not believed by anyone.

words.meaning: To criticize (someone or something) severely.
examples: The critics were quick to pan the new movie.
His latest novel was panned by all the major newspapers.

words.meaning: A solution or remedy for all difficulties or diseases.
examples: There is no panacea for all the world's problems.
He believes that education is the panacea for all social evils.

words.meaning: Flamboyant confidence of style or manner.
examples: He played the role with great panache and charm.
She has a panache that makes her stand out from the crowd.

words.meaning: (of a disease) prevalent over a whole country or the world.
examples: The COVID-19 pandemic had a devastating impact on the global economy.
Scientists are working to prevent the next pandemic.

words.meaning: Wild and noisy disorder or confusion; uproar.
examples: Pandemonium broke out when the rock star appeared on stage.
There was pandemonium in the streets after the team won the championship.

words.meaning: Gratify or indulge (an immoral or distasteful desire, need, or habit or a person with such a desire, etc.).
examples: The politician was accused of pandering to the voters' prejudices.
The media should not pander to the public's thirst for sensationalism.

words.meaning: A public speech or published text in praise of someone or something.
examples: He delivered a panegyric on the life and work of the late president.
The book is a panegyric to the joys of country living.

words.meaning: A sudden sharp pain or painful emotion.
examples: She felt pangs of guilt for having lied to her friend.
He experienced pangs of hunger after not eating all day.

words.meaning: Criticized severely.
examples: The new play was panned by the critics.
His performance in the movie was universally panned.

words.meaning: A complete or impressive collection of things.
examples: The museum displayed a panoply of ancient artifacts.
The wedding was a panoply of colors and traditions.

words.meaning: A simple story used to illustrate a moral or spiritual lesson.
examples: The story of the good Samaritan is a well-known parable.
He used a parable to explain the importance of forgiveness.

words.meaning: A typical example or pattern of something; a model.
examples: The discovery of DNA was a paradigm shift in the field of biology.
The company's success became a paradigm for others to follow.

words.meaning: Of the nature of a paradigm or model.
examples: The professor presented a paradigmatic case study to the class.
His career is a paradigmatic example of success through hard work.

words.meaning: A seemingly absurd or self-contradictory statement or proposition that when investigated or explained may prove to be well founded or true.
examples: It's a paradox that in a country with so much food, there are still people who go hungry.
The paradox of 'the more you learn, the less you know' is a profound one.

words.meaning: Seemingly absurd or self-contradictory.
examples: It is paradoxical that the quieter you are, the more you are heard.
He had a paradoxical nature, being both shy and outgoing.

words.meaning: A person or thing regarded as a perfect example of a particular quality.
examples: She was a paragon of virtue and an inspiration to everyone.
The hotel is a paragon of luxury and comfort.

words.meaning: More important than anything else; supreme.
examples: The safety of our passengers is of paramount importance.
It is paramount that we find a solution to this problem as soon as possible.

words.meaning: An organism that lives in or on an organism of another species (its host) and benefits by deriving nutrients at the other's expense.
examples: The tapeworm is a parasite that lives in the intestines of humans and other animals.
He considered his lazy brother-in-law to be a parasite on the family.

words.meaning: Trim (something) by cutting away its outer edges.
examples: She pared the apple before eating it.
The company had to pare down its expenses to avoid bankruptcy.

words.meaning: Relating to or inserted as a parenthesis.
examples: His parenthetical remarks, though interesting, distracted from the main point of his speech.
The author used a parenthetical comment to provide additional information.

words.meaning: An outcast.
examples: After the scandal, he was treated as a pariah by his former colleagues.
She felt like a pariah in her new school.

words.meaning: A conference between opposing sides in a dispute, especially a discussion of terms for an armistice.
examples: The two generals met for a parley to discuss a possible ceasefire.
After a brief parley, they agreed to a temporary truce.

words.meaning: Having a limited or narrow outlook or scope.
examples: His parochial views prevented him from understanding other cultures.
The small town had a very parochial atmosphere.

words.meaning: An imitation of the style of a particular writer, artist, or genre with deliberate exaggeration for comic effect.
examples: The comedian performed a hilarious parody of the president's speech.
The movie is a parody of the classic horror film genre.

words.meaning: A sudden attack or violent expression of a particular emotion or activity.
examples: He went into a paroxysm of rage when he heard the news.
She was seized by a paroxysm of coughing.

words.meaning: Inlaid work of blocks of various woods in a geometric pattern, used for flooring.
examples: The ballroom had a beautiful parquetry floor.
The skilled craftsman specialized in creating intricate parquetry designs.

words.meaning: Ward off (a weapon or attack) with a countermove.
examples: The fencer skillfully parried his opponent's thrust.
She parried the reporter's intrusive questions with a witty remark.

words.meaning: Unwilling to spend money or use resources; stingy or frugal.
examples: The parsimonious old man refused to turn on the heating, even in winter.
She was so parsimonious that she would reuse teabags.

words.meaning: Existing only in part; incomplete.
examples: He only has a partial understanding of the subject.
The road was closed due to a partial collapse of the bridge.

words.meaning: Unfair bias in favor of one thing or person compared with another; favoritism.
examples: The judge was accused of partiality towards the defendant.
She showed a partiality for sweet desserts.

words.meaning: A strong supporter of a party, cause, or person.
examples: The partisan crowd cheered loudly for their team.
The newspaper's coverage of the election was highly partisan.

words.meaning: A person of obscure origin who has gained wealth, influence, or celebrity.
examples: He was a parvenu who had made his fortune in the tech industry.
The old aristocracy looked down on the parvenus who had recently joined their ranks.

words.meaning: Shift the responsibility for something to someone else.
examples: Don't try to pass the buck; it's your responsibility to solve this problem.
The manager was accused of passing the buck and blaming his subordinates for his own mistakes.

words.meaning: No longer fashionable; out of date.
examples: His style of dress was considered passe by the younger generation.
That type of music is so passe now.

words.meaning: An artistic work in a style that imitates that of another work, artist, or period.
examples: The film is a pastiche of old-fashioned detective movies.
Her novel is a clever pastiche of 19th-century romance.

words.meaning: (especially of land or a farm) used for or related to the keeping or grazing of sheep or cattle.
examples: The pastoral landscape was dotted with grazing sheep.
He longed for a simple, pastoral life in the countryside.

words.meaning: Easily recognizable; obvious.
examples: The patent absurdity of his excuse was clear to everyone.
She told a patent lie, and everyone knew it.

words.meaning: Arousing pity, especially through vulnerability or sadness.
examples: The lost puppy looked so pathetic and helpless.
He made a pathetic attempt to apologize, but no one was convinced.

words.meaning: (of a bacterium, virus, or other microorganism) causing disease.
examples: The scientist was studying a pathogenic strain of bacteria.
Pathogenic microorganisms can be a serious threat to public health.

words.meaning: Involving, caused by, or of the nature of a physical or mental disease.
examples: He was a pathological liar who could not be trusted.
Her pathological fear of spiders made it difficult for her to go outside.

words.meaning: The science of the causes and effects of diseases, especially the branch of medicine that deals with the laboratory examination of samples of body tissue for diagnostic or forensic purposes.
examples: The pathology report confirmed the diagnosis of cancer.
He specialized in forensic pathology and worked with the police on criminal investigations.

words.meaning: A quality that evokes pity or sadness.
examples: The play was full of pathos, and many in the audience were moved to tears.
There was a great deal of pathos in her story of loss and survival.

words.meaning: The dialect of the common people of a region, differing in various respects from the standard language of the rest of the country.
examples: The locals spoke a patois that was difficult for outsiders to understand.
The author used a Jamaican patois to give his characters an authentic voice.

words.meaning: The male head of a family or tribe.
examples: The family patriarch was a respected elder in the community.
As the patriarch of the clan, his word was law.

words.meaning: Treat with an apparent kindness that betrays a feeling of superiority.
examples: Don't patronize me; I'm not a child.
She hated the way he would patronize her in front of their friends.

words.meaning: Treating with an apparent kindness that betrays a feeling of superiority.
examples: His patronizing tone made her feel small and insignificant.
She was tired of his patronizing attitude and condescending remarks.

words.meaning: The presence of something only in small or insufficient quantities or amounts; scarcity.
examples: There was a paucity of evidence to support his claim.
The paucity of clean water in the village was a major health concern.

words.meaning: A small stone made smooth and round by the action of water or sand.
examples: The children were collecting pebbles on the beach.
He skipped a pebble across the surface of the lake.

words.meaning: Strange or odd; unusual.
examples: The food had a peculiar taste that I couldn't quite identify.
He had a peculiar habit of talking to himself.
